A word of explanation to the reader

Preparing the questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences whereas may prove impossible for others so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra space or paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the question.

Don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events. If they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years at least four in his province or not.

It more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

May 5, 1955
PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

I don't know what they may have thought. I had never been there before.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train from London to Scotland, then to Liverpool, England, boat to Quebec, train to Winnipeg.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, excitement, etc.)

Nothing very exciting except in Quebec when I met a man who was going and when I told him he felt my hand.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I came to South Qu'Appelle by train once then walked to Fort Qu'Appelle 18 miles hence to join my family.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

The Edgely district 9 miles from Qu'Appelle.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

After filing on my homestead, I moved to Melfort, Saskatchewan about Nov. 1st, 1904 until May 1905.

18. How did you earn money before coming to Western Canada?

How, after you left school when I was fourteen, worked at various stations for two summers, farming and road construction, the rest of the year attended day school through the winter the first two winters.
